column2: formerly known as Fengtian (Chinese: 奉天) or by its Manchu name Mukden
column3: is a major sub-provincial city and the provincial capital of Liaoning province
column4: People's Republic of China.  Located in central-north Liaoning
column5: it is the province's most populous city as well as the largest city in Northeast China by urban population
column6: with an urban population of 6.3 million (2010 census)
column7: while the total metropolitan population is up to 8.1 million.  Shenyang is also the central city of one of the major megalopolises in China
column8: the Greater Shenyang Metropolitan Area
column9: with a total population over 23 million.  The city's administrative region includes the ten metropolitan districts of Shenyang proper
column10: the county-level city of Xinmin
column11: and two counties of Kangping and Faku.

column2: Shenyang was conquered by the Manchu people and briefly used as the capital of the Qing dynasty. The Battle of Mukden took place in 1905 as part of the Russo-Japanese War. Japan's subsequent victory allowed them to annex the region west of the old city and increase their influence on Shenyang; the Mukden Incident led the Japanese to further invade and occupy the rest of Northeast China
column3: creating the puppet state of Manchukuo.  After the Japanese surrender in 1945
column4: Shenyang remained a Kuomintang stronghold
column5: but was captured by the Communists in 1948 after the Liaoshen Campaign.

column2: Shenyang is an important industrial center in China
column3: and serves as the transportation and commercial hub of China's northeast—particularly with Japan
column4: Russia and Korea. A center of heavy industry in China since the 1930s
column5: and the spearhead of the Chinese central government's Northeast Area Revitalization Plan
column6: the city has been diversifying its industry
column7: including expanding into the service sector. Growing industries include software
column8: automotive and electronics.

column1: Shenyang is also a major city by scientific research among the top 200 Science Cities in the world
column2: as tracked by the Nature Index. The city is home to several major universities
column3: notably Northeastern University and Liaoning University
column4: members of China's prestigious universities in the Project 211.

column1: Shenyang literally means "the yang side of the Shen River" and refers to the location of the Hun River (formerly called the Shen River
column2: 瀋水; Shěn Shuǐ)
column3: on the southern side of the city.  According to Chinese naming tradition
column4: a river's north bank and a mountain's south slope are angled more towards direct sunlight and thus are considered the "sunny
column5: or yang
column6:
side.


== History ==


=== Ancient era ===

Archaeological findings show that humans resided in present-day Shenyang as early as 8,000 years ago. The remains of the Xinle culture, a late neolithic period society over 6,800–7,200 years old, are located in a museum in the north part of Huanggu District.  It is complemented by a recreated village on site. A wood-sculptured bird unearthed there is the earliest cultural relic in Shenyang, as well as one of oldest wood sculptures found anywhere in the world.
The city, now known as Shenyang, was first established in about 300 BCE during the Warring States period by Yan general Qin Kai, who conquered the Liaodong region, and was then named  Hou City (侯城; Hóu Chéng).  However, around 350 years later during the reign of Emperor Guangwu of Han, the city was sacked and burnt by the Donghu nomads and subsequently abandoned.  The area of modern Shenyang was divided between two commanderies called Liaodong and Xuantu around 107 CE. Liaodong was seized by a Han governor in 189.  Liaodong and Xuantu were briefly united under the Wei Dynasty and Jin Dynasty. The region was in disarray during the fourth century until the Koguryo occupied both commanderies in 404.  They established the cities of Xuantucheng and Gaimoucheng in the region.The Sui dynasty recaptured the area and established a new Liaodong Commandery in what is now modern Shenyang. In 645, the Tang sent forces to fight against Koguryo and they captured Xuantucheng and Gaimoucheng.  Soon after, Liaodong was administratively reorganized and enjoyed nearly 250 years of stability and development.In 916, the Shenyang region was ruled by the Liao dynasty and was known as the Shen Prefecture (瀋州; Shěn Zhōu) through to the end of Jin dynasty (who conquered the region in 1116), and became the Shenyang Circuit (瀋陽路; Shěnyáng Lù) during the Yuan dynasty.  During the Ming dynasty, it was designated as a guard town" (militarized settlements
column7: such as walled/heavily garrisoned cities or towns) named Shenyang Central Guard (瀋陽中衛; Shěnyáng Zhōngwèi) and gradually became one of the most important strongholds beyond the Shanhai Pass.

column2: the Manchu leader Nurhaci captured Shenyang and decided to relocate his entire administrative infrastructures to the city
column3: or Simiyan hoton (Manchu: ᠰᡳᠮᡳᠶᠠᠨ ᡥᠣᡨᠣᠨ) as it is called in Manchu language. The official name was changed to Shengjing (盛京; Shèng Jīng; 'rising capital')
column4: or  Mukden (Manchu: ᠮᡠᡴ᠋ᡩᡝᠨ)

column6: mukdembi (Manchu: ᠮᡠᡴ᠋ᡩᡝᠮᠪᡳ)
column7: meaning "to rise" as reflected also by its Han Chinese name.  Under Nurhaci's orders
column8: the Imperial Palace was constructed in 1626
column9: symbolizing the city's emerging status as the Jurchen political center.  The palace featured more than 300 ostentatiously decorated rooms and 20 gardens as a symbol of power and grandeur.After the fall of the Ming dynasty in 1644 and the routing of the Shun army in the Battle of Shanhai Pass merely a day later
column10: the Manchus successfully entered the Shanhai Pass to establish the Qing dynasty in China proper
column11: with the capital relocated to Beijing.  However
column12: Shenyang retained considerable importance as the secondary capital and the spiritual home of the Qing dynasty through the centuries.  Treasures of the royal house were kept at its palaces
column13: and the tombs of the early Qing rulers were once among the most famous monuments in China.  In 1657
column14: Fengtian Prefecture (奉天府; Fèngtiān Fŭ; Manchu: ᠠᠪᡴᠠᡳ ᡳᠮᡳᠶᠠᠩᡤᠠ ᡶᡠ; Möllendorff: abkai imiyangga fu; Abkai: abkai imiyangga fu or Manchu: ᡶᡠᠩ ᡨᡳᠶᠠᠨ; Möllendorff: fung tiyian; Abkai: fung tiyian) was established in the Shenyang area
column15: and Fengtian (lit.: 'mandated by Heaven') was sometimes used synonymously with Shenyang/Mukden.

column2: Japan coerced the annexation of the Liaodong Peninsula with the Treaty of Shimonoseki in 1895
column3: though was forced to give it up due to diplomatic pressure from the Triple Intervention.  In the aftermath of the Japanese threat
column4: Qing viceroy Li Hongzhang visited Moscow in 1896 and signed a secret treaty with Russian foreign minister Aleksey Lobanov-Rostovsky
column5: allowing Imperial Russia to build a Russian gauge railway in Manchuria
column6: which opened the door towards further Russian expansionism in the form of another lease convention in 1898
column7: effectively allowing Russia to annex Port Arthur in all but name.  However
column8: after the Boxer Rebellion in 1900
column9: Russian forces used the anti-foreigner insurgency as a pretext to formally invade and occupied most of Manchuria
column10: and Mukden became a Russian stronghold in the Far East with the building of the South Manchurian Railway.During the Russo-Japanese War (1904—1905)
column11: Mukden was the site of the Battle of Mukden from February 19 to March 10
column14: it was the largest battle since the Battle of Leipzig in 1813
column15: and also the largest modern-era battle ever fought in Asia before World War II.  Following the Japanese victory
column16: Mukden became one of the chief bases of Japanese presence and economic expansion into southern Manchuria. It also became the government seat of Fengtian province in 1910. It was during this time that Mukden was one of the main epicenters of the Manchurian plague (1910—1911)

column2: the city changed back to its old name Shenyang
column3: but continued to be known as Mukden (sometimes spelled Moukden) in some English sources and in Japan through much of the first half of 20th century. The postmark of the Chinese postal administration kept the spelling "MOUKDEN/奉天" for usage on international mails until the late 1920s.  After that
column4: a Chinese–Manchurian bilingual type "SHENYANG (MUKDEN)/瀋陽 (奉天)" datestamp was used until 1933.

column8: a small quantity of dynamite was detonated close to a railway line near Mukden owned by the Japanese South Manchuria Railway Company by Kwantung Army Lt. Kawamoto Suemori.  The Imperial Japanese Army
column9: accusing Chinese dissidents of the act
column10: then used the false flag explosion as pretext to launch a full attack on Mukden
column11: and captured the city the following morning (September 19).  After the Mukden Incident
column12: the Japanese further invaded and occupied the rest of Northeast China
column13: and created the puppet state of Manchukuo with the deposed emperor Aisin Gioro Puyi as the figurehead.  During the Manchukuo era (1932–1945)
column14: the city was again called Fengtian (and Mukden in English)
column15: and was developed by the Japanese into a center of heavy industry. Japan was able to exploit resources in Manchuria using the extensive network of railroads. For example
column16: vast expanses of Manchurian forest were chopped down. The development of Shenyang was also unbalanced in this period; municipal facilities were mostly located in Japanese residential areas
column17: while Chinese residential areas had poor living conditions.

column1: Under Marshal of the Soviet Union Aleksandr Vasilevsky
column2: the Far East Command of Soviet forces entered Manchuria in early August 1945 following the surrender of Japan. On 16 August 1945
column3: Manchurian Emperor Puyi was captured in Shenyang Airport by the Soviet Red Army while he was in an airplane fleeing to Japan. On 20 August
column4: Soviet troops captured Shenyang. British and US reports indicate that the Soviet troops that occupied Northeast China and Eastern Inner Mongolia region looted and terrorized the people of Shenyang
column5: and were not discouraged by Soviet authorities from "three days of rape and pillage". The Soviets were replaced by the Nationalist Chinese
column6: who were flown in on U.S. transport planes. During the Chinese Civil War
column7: Shenyang remained a Kuomintang stronghold from 1946 to 1948
column8: although the Chinese communists controlled the surrounding countryside. It was captured by the communists on October 30
column10: following a series of offensives known as the Liaoshen Campaign.Over the past 200 years or so
column11: Shenyang managed to grow and increase its industrial might during consecutive wars with Russia and Japan in the late 19th and early 20th centuries
column13: and China's Civil War (Shenyang became the main battleground between the Communists and Nationalists).

column1: The old city of Shenyang resided almost entirely within the modern day Shenhe District
column2: and used to have two city walls.Situated roughly within the area bounded by the four "Shuncheng" (顺城; 'along the city') roads/streets in Shenhe District
column3: the (now-demolished) square-shaped inner city wall marked the bounds of ancient Shenyang.  The earliest wall was built in 926 during early Liao dynasty to settle Northern Song civilians the Khitans abducted from raids to use as slave labourers
column4: and was then made of rammed earth because the city was merely a small settlement at the time (historically the administrative center of the Liaodong region was at Liaoyang).  However
column6: Hongwu Emperor of the newly founded Ming dynasty ordered a new regional military command—the Liaodong Regional Military Commission (遼東都指揮使司)—to be established
column7: and Shenyang was made a prominent regional "guard town" (衛所).  In 1388
column8: Min Zhong (閔忠)
column9: the newly appointed city commissioner of the Shenyang Central Guard
column10: wrote to Hongwu Emperor immediately upon his tenure requesting permission to upgrade the city wall
column11: and the old wall was made taller and thoroughly reinforced with overlaid bricks.  According to History of Ming
column12: the reconstructed Ming-era wall was 2.5 zhàng (8 metres or 26 feet) tall
column13: more than 1 zhàng (3.2 metres or 10.5 feet) wide at the top
column14: and 9 li and 30 bu (about 5.2 kilometres or 3.2 miles) long.  It has two layers of moats dug outside
column15: each being 3 zhàng (9.6 metres or 31.5 feet) wide and 8 chi (2.56 metres or 8 feet 4.8 inches) deep
column16: fed with water from the Little Shen River (the present day South Canal).  There were four city gates
column17: each at the center of one side
column18: connected by two main roads that intersected at Central Temple of the city's center in a "+" fashion.

column1: This Ming wall was heavily damaged in 1625 when the Manchus laid siege and captured the city
column2: with only the north wall and gate tower (which had undergone reinforcing reconstructions in 1545 under the orders of Jiajing Emperor) remained intact.  The Manchu leader Nurhachi however saw the city's strategic value and decided to formally relocate his Later Jin capital from Liaoyang to Shenyang
column3: and ordered the wall to be rebuilt.  According to Annals of Mukden (盛京通志)
column4: the new city wall was a standard black brick wall standing at a height of 3.5 zhàng (about 12.5 metres or 41.0 feet)
column5: a width of 1.8 zhàng (about 6.4 metres or 21.0 feet) and a total length of 9 li and 332 bu (about 6.4 kilometres or 4.0 miles)
column6: complete with 12 towers (8 gates and 4 corners) and a widened 14.5-zhàng (about 52-metre or 171-foot) moat.  The city gates were increased from four to eight
column7: though the old Ming-era north gate tower was preserved but sealed shut
column8: later known as the "Ninth Gate" (九門).

column2: called the "peripheral wall" (邊牆; Biān Qiáng) or "pass wall" (關牆; Guān Qiáng)
column3: was actually a rammed earth rampart built in 1680 to expand the urban area outside the inner city.  It was almost round in shape
column4: standing at a height of 7.5 chi (around 2.7 metres or 8 feet 10.3 inches) and an overall length of 32 li and 24 bu (about 20.7 kilometres or 12.9 miles)
column5: and also had eight towerless gates known as the "peripheral gates" (邊門; Biān Mén).  The corresponding inner and outer gates were linked by roads that intersected within the inner city in a "#" pattern around the Mukden Palace.

column1: Nearly all of these city walls and gates were demolished after 1949.  Two gates and one corner tower of the inner wall were rebuilt during the 1990s.  There had
column2: however

column1: Both the Temple of Heaven and Temple of Earth were also to be found in the old city during the Qing dynasty.  They were smaller replicas of Beijing's counterparts. Neither exists today.
Shenyang ranges in latitude from 41° 11' to 43° 02' N and in longitude from 122° 25' to 123° 48' E
column2: and is located in the central part of Liaoning province.  The western parts of the city's administrative area are located on the alluvial plain of the Liao River system
column3: while the eastern part consists of the hinterlands of the Changbai Mountains
column4: and is covered with forests.  The highest point in Shenyang is 414 m (1
column5: 358 ft) above sea level and the lowest point only 7 m (23 ft).  The average elevation of the urban area is 45 m (148 ft).The city's main urban area is located to the north of Hun River
column6: formerly the largest tributary of the Liao River proper and often locally referred as the city's "mother river".  The central urban area is surrounded by three artificial rivers—respectively the South Canal (南运河) from the south and southeast
column7: the Xinkai River (新开河
column8: formerly the North Canal) from the north and northeast
column9: and the Weigong River (卫工河
column10: formerly the Weigong Nullah) from the west
column11: all interconnected by channels as a continuous waterway.  The South Canal in particular

column13: was constructed upon the old course of the Wanquan River (萬泉河; 'ten thousand springs river')
column14: historically also called the Little Shen River (小瀋水) or Wuli River (五里河; 'five-li river')
column15: which was a principal water source for the old city.   These are reinforced on the peripheries by smaller rivers such as Xi River (细河)
column16: Puhe River (蒲河) and Mantang River (满堂河)
column17: and drains into the Hun River at three different locations on the southeast
column18: due south and southwest side of the city.  There was also previously another canal on the east side called Huishan Nullah (辉山明渠) that drains into Xinkai River's lower section
column19: but is now no longer existent due to land reclamation from urban constructions.

column1: According to the Shenyang Environmental Protection Bureau
column2: winter usage of coal by boiler stations for hydronic district heating is the source of 30 percent of the air pollution in Shenyang.  Half of the 16 million metric tons of coal consumed by the city during the winter of 2013–2014 were used for heating.  Other major factors include dust from construction sites (20 percent)
column3: vehicle exhaust (20 percent)
column4: industrial emissions (10 percent) and extraterritorial dust (20 percent
column5: mostly yellow dust from Gobi Desert).  However
column6: air quality was described by the Bureau as "slowly improving".

column1: Shenyang has a monsoon-influenced humid continental climate (Köppen Dwa) characterised by hot
column2: humid summers due to the monsoon
column3: and dry
column4: cold winters due to the Siberian anticyclone.  The four seasons here are distinctive.  Nearly half of the annual rainfall occurs in July and August.  Monthly mean temperatures range from −11.2 °C (11.8 °F) in January to 24.6 °C (76.3 °F) in July
column5: for an annual average of 8.53 °C (47.4 °F).  The frost-free period is 183 days
column6: which is long considering the severity of the winters.  The city receives 2
column7: 468 hours of bright sunshine annually; monthly percent of possible ranges from 45 percent in July to 62 percent in October.  Extreme temperatures range from −33.1 °C (−28 °F) to 39.3 °C (103 °F).

The city center specialises in retail and financial services.Out of the rural counties

column1: The district is featured in a 9-hour epic documentary film West of the Tracks by a young filmmaker Wang Bing. It shows the transition in this rust belt district—a palimpsest of not only Chinese but also world history. The first factories of this place were built in 1934 by the Japanese to produce war goods for the Imperial Army and nationalized after World War II.  As late as the early 1980s
column2: the factories here employed about one million workers

column1: Shenyang is an important industrial center in China and is the core city of Shenyang Economic Zone
column2: a New Special Reform Zone.  It has been focused on heavy industry
column3: particularly aerospace
column4: machine tools
column5: heavy equipment and defence
column6: and recently on software
column7: automotive and electronics. The heavy industry started in the 1920s and was well developed before the second world war. During the first five-year plan (1951–1956) many factories were built in Tiexi district. At its peak in the 1970s
column8: Shenyang was one of the top three industrial centers in China alongside Shanghai and Tianjin
column9: and was at one time being considered for upgrading to a direct-controlled municipality.  However
column10: as the planned economy fell out of favor after the 1980s
column11: the heavy industry had declined gradually and the city became a rust belt city
column12: with hundreds of thousands of people laid off from bankrupted state-owned factories. Nonetheless
column13: the economy of the city has revived significantly in recent years
column14: thanks to the central government's "Revitalize Northeast China" campaign and the rapid development of software and auto manufacture industries. Investment subsidies are granted to multinational corporations (MNCs) that set up offices or headquarters in Shenyang.The services sector—especially banking—has been developing in Shenyang. Shenyang has several foreign banks
column15: such as South Korea's Hana Bank
column17: Hong Kong's Bank of East Asia
column18: Singapore's United Overseas Bank and the Britain-based HSBC.  In 2006
column19: the city hosted a total of 1
column20: 063 banks and bank branches and 144 insurance-related companies. By 2010
column21: it aims to attract 30 foreign banks and 60 non-bank financial institutions.The city has been identified by the Economist Intelligence Unit in the November 2010 Access China White Paper as a member of the CHAMPS (Chongqing
column26: an economic profile of the top 20 emerging cities in China.Shenyang has three development zones:

column1: Shenyang Finance and Trade Development Zone
Numerous major industrial companies have their headquarters in Shenyang.  Brilliance Auto is a major Chinese automobile manufacturer
column2: and most of its production plants are also located in Shenyang.  Shenyang Aircraft Corporation produces airplanes for civilian use as well as for the PLAAF.  Neusoft Group is the biggest software company in China.  Shenyang Machine Tool Group is the largest machine tool manufacturer in China.  Tyco International
column3: General Motors and Michelin Shenyang Tyre Corporation are expanding their operations in Shenyang.

column1: The GDP per capita of the city of Shenyang is 78490 yuan in 2009 (ranked 3rd out of all 58 cities and counties in Liaoning province).
As the transport hub of Northeast China
column2: Shenyang is served by air
column3: rail
column4: a currently two-line subway system and an extensive network of streets and expressways
column5: with bus service throughout the city. Terminal 3 at Shenyang Taoxian International Airport is the largest terminal in the northeast China. A new tram network system was built in the city's south in 2013.

column1: Shenyang is the railway hub of Northeast China.  Eight railways connect Shenyang with Beijing
column2: Dalian
column3: Changchun
column4: Harbin and Fushun.  The city is also served by the Qinhuangdao–Shenyang high-speed railway
column5: the main passenger transport corridor in and out across the Shanhai Pass
column6: and the first passenger-specific railway line in China.  In early 2007
column7: a 200 km/h (120 mph) high-speed train decreased travel time between Beijing and Shenyang by almost three-fold to around 4 hours. The Harbin–Dalian high-speed railway opened in late 2012 and connects Shenyang with other major cities in Northeast China such as Harbin
column8: Changchun and Dalian at speeds of up to 300 km/h (190 mph).Shenyang has two major railway stations: the Shenyang North railway station in Shenhe District
column9: and the Shenyang railway station in Heping District.

column1: The Shenyang North Railway Station (Chinese: 沈阳北站; pinyin: Shěnyáng Bĕi Zhàn) was formerly the Liaoning General Station (遼寧總站; Liáoníng Zǒngzhàn) before 1946
column2: and colloquially known as the "Old North Station".  The original station building (now an MHCSPNL-listed heritage building)
column3: initially named the Fengtian City Station (奉天城站; Fèngtīan Chéng Zhàn) at the time of completion
column4: was built in 1927 at the terminal point of Jingfeng Railway
column5: about 1 km (0.62 mi) southwest of the current station site
column6: on the orders of warlord Zhang Zuolin to compete with the then Japanese-administered Shenyang Railway Station.  The Main Station Building (主站房) of the current "New North Station" began construction in 1986 and was commissioned for operation in December 1990
column7: and became one of the five most important railway hubs in China
column8: earning itself the nickname "Northeast's No. 1 Station" (东北第一站).  In 2011
column9: a huge expansion project known as the "North Station Transport Hub Reconstruction Project" (北站交通枢纽改造工程) was initiated in response to the growing demand of floor area posed by the increasing passenger traffic after introduction of the high-speed rail service.  The station now has an additional 3-storey "Sub-Station Building" (子站房) and a "North Square" (北广场) on the northern (Huanggu District) side of the railways
column10: while the old waiting lounge in the original 16-storey Main Station Building is now relocated to a large elevated concourse that bridges over the rail tracks
column11: with a pillar-less roof (the largest in mainland China) doming the platforms.  The original South Square (南广场) outside the Main Station Building was rebuilt into a multi-levelled complex
column12: with two above ground forming an elevated airport-style drop-off zone and a large ground-level area for bus stops
column13: as well as a three-level underground city providing shopping malls
column15: taxi pick-up and interchange with Subway Line 2
column16: while also capable of rapid conversion into an air raid shelter if needed.

column1: The Shenyang Railway Station (Chinese: 沈阳站; pinyin: Shěnyáng Zhàn) has a history of more than 100 years.  It was built by the Russians in 1899 on the eastern side of the South Manchurian Railway and was named the Fengtian Station (Chinese: 奉天站; pinyin: Fèngtiān Zhàn) at the time.  It was later expanded by the Japanese after the Russo-Japanese War and renamed to Fengtian Yam (Chinese: 奉天驛; pinyin: Fèngtiān Yì) until the end of the World War II.  Before adopting its current name
column2: the station was known as the Shenyang South Railway Station (Chinese: 瀋陽南站; pinyin: Shĕnyáng Nán Zhàn) or simply the "South Station" (in contrast to the forementioned "North Station") between 1945 and 1950
column3: a name the locals still use colloquially to present days (though the current Shenyang South railway station is actually at the suburban junction between Hunnan and Sujiatun).  Today
column4: the station focuses on regular-speed passenger service and is being refurbished with a large archway and new terminal
column5: reducing access to the boarding platforms by rerouting customers under and over ground while construction is completed.  The station was expanded in 2010 with the addition of a new West Station Building (西站房) and a West Square (西广场) on the western side of the railways.  The old East Station Building (东站房) is currently on the provincial protected heritage list.

column2: the initial road transportation network was laid out
column3: as is now in the central districts of Shenyang.  The city follows a largely grid-style urban layout
column4: with the roads follow a slightly tilted northwest-to-southeast orientation due to the South Manchurian Railway
column5: which runs perpendicular to that direction.  The streets in Shenyang are almost always named according to a routine convention — one that runs more in the north–south direction is called a "street" (街; Jīe) or "avenue" (大街; Dà Jīe; 'big street')
column6: and one that runs more east–west are call a "road" (路; Lù) or "boulevard" (大道; Dà Dào; 'big path').  The only exceptions to this rule are the east-west Middle Street in Shenhe District
column7: which takes its historical name from ancient times (though its modern official name is actually the "Middle Street Road"); and the north-south Minzhu Road (民主路) in Heping District that traverses diagonally across the superblock between the Shenyang Railway Station and the Zhongshan Park
column8: but as one of the only three diagonal streets in the entire city it is accommodated as a "road" instead of "street" in keeping with the other two diagonal counterparts that run east–west.

column1: In addition to the grid streets
column2: Shenyang also was developing several ring road systems
column3: going back as early as the "Fengtian City Plan" (奉天都邑計劃) proposed by the Japanese-controlled puppet Manchukuo government in 1932.  Outside of the (now demolished) city walls
column4: the city initially planned three beltways
column5: namely the "inner ring"
column6: "middle ring" and "outer ring" roads.  Gradually with urban development
column7: the inner ring idea faded away into the inner city grids
column8: but the middle ring concept was retained and later transformed into the nowadays 1st Ring Road (一环路
column9: officially called the "Middle Ring Road" until 1995)
column10: and the outer ring morphed roughly into parts of the present day 2nd Ring Road (二环路).  The 3rd Ring Road (三环路) was completed in 1995
column11: and in 2013 was upgraded into an 8-lane
column12: 82 km (51 mi) freeway—the G1501 Shenyang Ring Expressway (沈阳绕城高速公路).  The 10-lane
column13: 132 km (82 mi) 4th Ring Road (四环路) is a limited-access highway about 8 km (5.0 mi) out from the 3rd Ring
column15: 198 km (123 mi) 5th Ring Road (五环路) and the proposed 399 km (248 mi) 6th Ring Road (六环路)
column16: also known as the G91 Liaozhong Ring Expressway (辽中环线高速公路)

column1: Shenyang is connected to the other regions by several major expressways in radial pattern.  The G15 Shenda Expressway (沈大高速公路) to the southwest is the first expressway built in China and is an 8-lane
column2: 348.5 km (216.5 mi) controlled-access highway with a maximum speed limit of 120 km/h (75 mph)

column4: one of the largest port city in China.  The 222 km (138 mi) Shendan Expressway (沈丹高速公路) to the southeast

column8: linking Shenyang to Jilin via Fushun.  The 8-lane Jingshen Expressway (京沈高速公路) to the west is an integral part of the extended G1 Jingha Expressway (京哈高速公路) beyond the northeast
column9: and is a major interprovincial "trunk road" across the Shanhai Pass linking to the national capital Beijing some 658 km (409 mi) away.  There are other smaller provincial-level expressways ("S routes") to other cities like Fushun

column11: as well as many long-distance and express bus routes to Beijing and other large Northeastern regional centers via major national roads such as the China National Highways 101

The Yuhong Airport (于洪机场) in Yuhong District is commissioned for military use only by the local Northern Theater Command garrisons.

column1: Mukden Palace (沈阳故宫): the former imperial palace of the early Qing dynasty.  It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
East Mausoleum (东陵): the tomb of the first Qing emperor
column2: Nurhaci.  It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

column1: Beiling Park and North Mausoleum (北陵): the tomb of the second Qing emperor
column2: Huang Taiji.  The park covers an area of 3
column4: 000 square metres (36
column6: 000 square feet)
column7: and is serviced by trams for visitors who do not wish to (or cannot) traverse the length of the park. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

column1: Qipan Mountain (棋盘山): a recreation resort in Shenbei New District
column2: northeast of Shenyang.

column1: Strange Slope (怪坡): an 80 m (87 yd)-long
column2: 25 m (82 ft)-wide slope on the western side of Mao Mountain in Shenbei District
column3: famous for the unexplained phenomenon of vehicles seemingly able to move uphill unpowered.

column1: Shenyang Botanical Garden  (沈阳植物园) is located within the Qipanshan Tourism District. With a total area of 2.46 km2 (610 acres)
column2: the garden hosted the International Horticultural Exposition in 2006.  Since then it has also been known as the Shenyang International Expo Garden (沈阳世博园). A variety of botanical exhibitions are held throughout the year.

column1: Meteorite Mountain Forest Park (陨石山森林公园)
column2: located in the southeast of Shenyang in Hunnan District.  The biggest meteorite lies on the Huashitai Mountain of Lixiang County
column3: and is 160 m (520 ft) long
column4: 54 m (177 ft) wide
column5: 42 m (138 ft) tall and about 2
column9: 000 short tons) in weight. It is the oldest meteorite in the world which was formed 4.5 billion years ago and fallen into the Earth 1.9 billion years ago.

column1: Xiaonan Cathedral of Shenyang (小南天主教堂)
column2: the construction of the cathedral started in 1875 and finished in 1878.

column1: Shenyang has many shopping areas that provide necessities
column2: luxuries and entertainments. One of the shopping districts is Middle Street (中街). Middle Street has a history of more than 100 years. In 2005
column3: Middle Street gained the title of China top 10 famous commercial shopping streets and in 2008; it won the International Golden Street title. Middle Street is also the first commercial pedestrian street in China.  Middle Street features many western-style stores and restaurants
column4: including Wal-Mart
column5: Pizza Hut
column6: Louis Vuitton flagship store
column7: Häagen-Dazs retail store
column8: etc. The largest shopping mall in Shenyang is also located on Middle Street
column9: selling products from all around the world.

column1: Taiyuan Street (太原街) is another shopping area which is similar to Middle Street. Taiyuan Street also features many restaurants and theaters for people to enjoy. Many spend their holidays shopping on these two streets. There is also a very large underground shopping center
column2: offering many items
column3: especially fashion jewelries
column4: accessories and clothing.

column2: Wu'ai Market (五爱市场)
column3: features a large multi-story shopping center with a size comparable to that of many city blocks.  It is famous for wholesaling cheap clothes and household items.

column1: The information technology center is in Sanhao street (三好街) in the southern part of the city. There are large superstores located throughout the city that sell everything from meat and dairy to clothes and electronics.
Shenyang has one of the highest concentrations of educational institutes in China. Roughly 30 colleges and universities and numerous research and training institutions are located in Shenyang
column2: including core institutes of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Fengyong University (馮庸大學) was the first private university in China to follow western teaching methods.  It was established on August 8
column2: 1927 with private funding by retired Fengtian clique major general Feng Yong (馮庸
column4: later re-enlisted as a ROCAF lieutenant general).  It contained the departments of Engineering
column5: Law and Education.  After the Mukden Incident
column6: the campus was looted by Japanese troops and converted into an aircraft repair camp.  The staffs and students were later forced to evacuate to Beiping
column7: where the university continued teaching for two more years before merging with the National Northeastern University in September
column8: 1933.  Many of the university's alumni were active members of anti-Japanese volunteer armies.
